keyTakeAways: A Colombian appeals court has overturned the conviction of former President Alvaro Uribe for fraud and bribery, citing structural deficiencies in the prior ruling.
This is the first time in Colombia’s history that a former president has been convicted of a crime, making the case historically significant.
The ruling has intensified political divisions, with critics accusing the judiciary of covering up right-wing paramilitary abuses.
The case has drawn international attention, particularly from U.S. political figures like Donald Trump and Marco Rubio, who have expressed concern over judicial bias toward conservative leaders.
The decision may influence the 2026 presidential election, potentially shifting political alliances and public sentiment in favor of Uribe.
Senator Ivan Cepeda plans to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court, indicating that the legal battle is far from concluded.
The case highlights ongoing tensions between Colombia’s political left and right, especially regarding the role of paramilitary groups and state violence during decades of internal conflict.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Colombian appeals court has overturned the 2018 conviction of former President Alvaro Uribe for fraud and witness tampering, citing structural flaws in the original ruling. This marks the first time a former Colombian president has been convicted of a crime, sparking intense political debate. Critics, including current President Gustavo Petro, argue that the decision covers up historical ties between right-wing politicians and paramilitary groups. The ruling has reignited a long-standing legal battle, with Senator Ivan Cepeda planning to appeal to the Supreme Court. The case is central to Colombia’s political landscape, with implications for the 2026 presidential election and international perceptions of judicial independence, especially amid U.S. political figures like Donald Trump and Marco Rubio criticizing the judiciary’s handling of conservative leaders.
title: Colombian appeals court strikes down ex-President Uribe’s conviction
